In each round, you will first receive the last messages sent by your neighbors and then be asked to generate your response messages which your neighbors receive in the next round. This process repeats for 8 rounds of message passing. Importantly, the process is synchronous: Every agent decides on which messages to send at the same time and sees the messages from other agents only in the next round.
4. Everybody (including you) decides what to share or request from neighbors. In every round, think step-by-step about the next set of messages you want to send. Output a JSON string that contains your response messages.
5. The messages you send to your neighbors are formatted as JSON. For example, if your neighbors are Alan and Bob, your output should look as follows: 
```
{
    "Alan": "Message that will be sent to Alan.",
    "Bob": "Message that will be sent to Bob.",
}
```
It is not mandatory to send a message to every neighbor in every round. If you do not want to send a message to a particular neighbor, you may omit their name from the JSON.
6. After 8 message passes, you have to solve the following task: You will be requested to state whether you are a coordinator. The response should either be 'Yes' or 'No'.

2. **Gather information**: In this initial round, it would be best to request information from Nicholas. I want to know if Nicholas has any thoughts or initial strategies on who should be a coordinator. 3. **Share my own thoughts**: I should also express my intention to find a way to designate the coordinators and clarify the objectives so that we are on the same page.

Considering these points, my messages to my neighbors (only Nicholas, in this case) would involve introducing the idea of discussing coordinators and asking for their input on which agent to include in this role.
